docs.title: Work organization
docs.text: The directory where all the rules for the team's work with the project are stored.

docs.title: Instalation
docs.text: The directory where all the necessary guides and documentation for installing and setting up the project are stored.

docs.title: Database
docs.text: The directory where all the information related to the project's database, including model descriptions, migrations, and other relevant database-related information are stored.

docs.title: Tools
docs.text: The directory where descriptions of all the tools used in/for the project are stored.

docs.title: Requirements (założenia projektowe, diagramy przypadków/użycia)
docs.text: The directory where all the project's requirements including diagrams are stored.

docs.title: Tests
docs.text: The directory where tests related tasks descriptions are stored

docs.text: Author: [Insert Author Name]

docs.title: How to Create a Migration
docs.text:
1. Step: >Brief description
  2. Step 2: >Brief description 2
  3. Step 3: >Brief description 3

  4. Step 4: >Brief description 4

  5. Example:

    1. Generate the Migration: >Run python manage.py makemigrations to generate the migration file.
    2. Apply the Migration: >Run python manage.py migrate to apply changes to the database.

docs.title: Models
docs.text: Author: [Insert Author Name]

docs.title: Model Name:
docs.text: Model name - Example: Subject

docs.title: Description:
docs.text: A brief description of what the model represents - Example: Subject is a structured unit of study within an academic program that focuses on a specific area of knowledge.

docs.title: Relationships & Dependencies
docs.text: Describe how this model connects with others. - Example: Subject references Department for organizational structure and Professor for the assigned lecturer. Each Subject can have multiple Student enrollments, establishing a one-to-many relationship

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: Additional tips or context for developers. - Example: "Ensure email uniqueness when integrating the User model."

docs.title: Markdown Tutorial
docs.text:
• Markdown Tutorial - site version
  • Markdown Tutorial - Youtube version

docs.title: Headings (#)
docs.text:
Created by putting one to six # symbols in front of your heading text.

# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3
#### Heading 4
##### Heading 5
###### Heading 6

docs.title: Paragraphs
docs.text:
If you just type text, it will automatically be converted into a paragraph.

This is a paragraph.

docs.title: Text Styling (* _ ** __)
docs.text:
Use one * or _ to italicize text and two * or _ to bold text.

*This is italicized text*  
_This is also italicized text_  

**This is bold text**  
__This is also bold text__

To make text both bold and italicized, wrap it in three * or _.

***This is both***  
___This is also both___


## Inline Code (`)
**Wrap your code in a single backtick (`) to format it as inline code.**


This is `inline code tutorial` within a paragraph.


## Code Blocks (```)
**For multi-line code blocks, wrap your code with three backticks. Optionally, specify the language for syntax highlighting.**


```py
class Calculator:
    def __init__(self, num1, num2):
        self.num1 = num1
        self.num2 = num2

docs.title: Lists (- * 1. 2.)
docs.text:
To create an unordered list, add -, *, or + before each item. For an ordered list, use numbers followed by a . character.

- This is an unordered list
- Of items

1. This is an ordered list
2. The numbers do not matter
3. This says 3
   * This is a nested list
   * Of items
      1. This is a nested
      2. List of items

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
To create a table, use | to separate columns and | at the start and end of each row. The second row must contain three or more - for each column, with : optionally added to control text alignment.

Col 1 Col 2 This is an example table with two columns Right Center Left R C L Head One Head Two Does Not Need To Be Aligned Properly
